result.markdown:
---
title: "Analise e Transformação de Dados"
format: html
editor: visual
editor_options: 
chunk_output_type: console
warning: false
mensage: false
---


## Pacote perfomance e DHARMa

O pacote performance no RStudio oferece diversas funções para avaliar o desempenho de modelos de aprendizado de máquina, principalmente no contexto de classificação e regressão.

O pacote DHARMa no RStudio oferece ferramentas para análise de resíduos de modelos de regressão linear mista (generalizada) hierárquicos (multi-nível).


::: {.cell hash='aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_166c92922313d11a05524df4bcd7cdc6'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
library(gsheet)
library(ggthemes)
library(performance)
library(DHARMa)
library(emmeans)
library(multcomp)
library(agricolae)
library(car)
library(MASS)

inseticida <- InsectSprays


inseticida |>
  ggplot(aes(spray, count))+
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## Anova

A ANOVA testa se existe pelo menos uma diferença significativa entre as médias dos grupos. Se o teste for significativo, significa que pelo menos um grupo possui uma média diferente dos demais.


::: {.cell hash='aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_85345754854eb55c35ed7bdb05ba5dba'}

```{.r .cell-code}
m1 <- lm(count ~ spray,
         data = inseticida)

anova(m1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Analysis of Variance Table

Response: count
          Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value    Pr(>F)    
spray      5 2668.8  533.77  34.702 < 2.2e-16 ***
Residuals 66 1015.2   15.38                      
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
m1$residuals
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
          1           2           3           4           5           6 
-4.50000000 -7.50000000  5.50000000 -0.50000000 -0.50000000 -2.50000000 
          7           8           9          10          11          12 
-4.50000000  8.50000000  2.50000000  5.50000000 -0.50000000 -1.50000000 
         13          14          15          16          17          18 
-4.33333333  1.66666667  5.66666667 -4.33333333  0.66666667 -1.33333333 
         19          20          21          22          23          24 
 1.66666667  1.66666667  3.66666667  5.66666667 -8.33333333 -2.33333333 
         25          26          27          28          29          30 
-2.08333333 -1.08333333  4.91666667 -0.08333333  0.91666667 -1.08333333 
         31          32          33          34          35          36 
-0.08333333 -1.08333333  0.91666667 -2.08333333 -1.08333333  1.91666667 
         37          38          39          40          41          42 
-1.91666667  0.08333333  7.08333333  1.08333333 -0.91666667 -1.91666667 
         43          44          45          46          47          48 
 0.08333333  0.08333333  0.08333333  0.08333333 -2.91666667 -0.91666667 
         49          50          51          52          53          54 
-0.50000000  1.50000000 -0.50000000  1.50000000 -0.50000000  2.50000000 
         55          56          57          58          59          60 
-2.50000000 -2.50000000 -0.50000000 -1.50000000  2.50000000  0.50000000 
         61          62          63          64          65          66 
-5.66666667 -7.66666667 -1.66666667  5.33333333 -1.66666667 -0.66666667 
         67          68          69          70          71          72 
-3.66666667 -6.66666667  9.33333333  9.33333333  7.33333333 -3.66666667 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
hist(m1$residuals)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
qqnorm(m1$residuals)
qqline(m1$residuals)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-2.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
shapiro.test(m1$residuals)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  m1$residuals
W = 0.96006, p-value = 0.02226
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
bartlett.test(count ~spray,
              data = inseticida)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Bartlett test of homogeneity of variances

data:  count by spray
Bartlett's K-squared = 25.96, df = 5, p-value = 9.085e-05
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_normality(m1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Warning: Non-normality of residuals detected (p = 0.022).
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_heteroscedasticity(m1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Warning: Heteroscedasticity (non-constant error variance) detected (p < .001).
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(simulateResiduals(m1))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-3.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## Transformação Por Raiz Quadrada

A transformação de raiz quadrada é útil para lidar com dados que apresentam heterocedasticidade, ou seja, quando a variância dos dados aumenta com a média.


::: {.cell hash='aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_46c773ddfd86cb80096ea08f9bc724ea'}

```{.r .cell-code}
inseticida <- inseticida |>
  mutate(count2 = sqrt(count))

inseticida |>
  ggplot(aes(spray, count2))+
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## Teste Com Dados Transformados


::: {.cell hash='aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_46b6866a0e533406c885528e6c7cde1c'}

```{.r .cell-code}
m2 <- lm(count2 ~ spray,
         data = inseticida)

anova(m2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Analysis of Variance Table

Response: count2
          Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value    Pr(>F)    
spray      5 88.438 17.6876  44.799 < 2.2e-16 ***
Residuals 66 26.058  0.3948                      
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
m1$residuals
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
          1           2           3           4           5           6 
-4.50000000 -7.50000000  5.50000000 -0.50000000 -0.50000000 -2.50000000 
          7           8           9          10          11          12 
-4.50000000  8.50000000  2.50000000  5.50000000 -0.50000000 -1.50000000 
         13          14          15          16          17          18 
-4.33333333  1.66666667  5.66666667 -4.33333333  0.66666667 -1.33333333 
         19          20          21          22          23          24 
 1.66666667  1.66666667  3.66666667  5.66666667 -8.33333333 -2.33333333 
         25          26          27          28          29          30 
-2.08333333 -1.08333333  4.91666667 -0.08333333  0.91666667 -1.08333333 
         31          32          33          34          35          36 
-0.08333333 -1.08333333  0.91666667 -2.08333333 -1.08333333  1.91666667 
         37          38          39          40          41          42 
-1.91666667  0.08333333  7.08333333  1.08333333 -0.91666667 -1.91666667 
         43          44          45          46          47          48 
 0.08333333  0.08333333  0.08333333  0.08333333 -2.91666667 -0.91666667 
         49          50          51          52          53          54 
-0.50000000  1.50000000 -0.50000000  1.50000000 -0.50000000  2.50000000 
         55          56          57          58          59          60 
-2.50000000 -2.50000000 -0.50000000 -1.50000000  2.50000000  0.50000000 
         61          62          63          64          65          66 
-5.66666667 -7.66666667 -1.66666667  5.33333333 -1.66666667 -0.66666667 
         67          68          69          70          71          72 
-3.66666667 -6.66666667  9.33333333  9.33333333  7.33333333 -3.66666667 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
hist(m2$residuals)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
qqnorm(m2$residuals)
qqline(m2$residuals)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-2.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
shapiro.test(m2$residuals)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  m2$residuals
W = 0.98721, p-value = 0.6814
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
bartlett.test(count ~spray,
              data = inseticida)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Bartlett test of homogeneity of variances

data:  count by spray
Bartlett's K-squared = 25.96, df = 5, p-value = 9.085e-05
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_normality(m2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
OK: residuals appear as normally distributed (p = 0.681).
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_heteroscedasticity(m2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
OK: Error variance appears to be homoscedastic (p = 0.854).
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(simulateResiduals(m2))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-3.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## Pacote emmeans

O pacote emmeans no RStudio oferece ferramentas para realizar análises de médias ajustadas em modelos de regressão linear e modelos de ANOVA. A principal função do pacote emmeans é a função emmeans(), que permite calcular as médias ajustadas para cada nível de um fator, controlando por outros fatores no modelo.


::: {.cell hash='aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_75b6508c3c32781e51fa85c7f96f787d'}

```{.r .cell-code}
m2_medias <- emmeans(m2, ~ spray)
plot(m2_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
cld(m2_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
 spray emmean    SE df lower.CL upper.CL .group
 C       1.24 0.181 66    0.883     1.61  1    
 E       1.81 0.181 66    1.447     2.17  12   
 D       2.16 0.181 66    1.802     2.53   2   
 A       3.76 0.181 66    3.399     4.12    3  
 B       3.88 0.181 66    3.514     4.24    3  
 F       4.02 0.181 66    3.656     4.38    3  

Confidence level used: 0.95 
P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 6 estimates 
significance level used: alpha = 0.05 
NOTE: If two or more means share the same grouping symbol,
      then we cannot show them to be different.
      But we also did not show them to be the same. 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
pwpm(m2_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
       A      B      C      D      E      F
A [3.76] 0.9975 <.0001 <.0001 <.0001 0.9145
B -0.116 [3.88] <.0001 <.0001 <.0001 0.9936

E  1.951  2.067 -0.565  0.355 [1.81] <.0001
F -0.258 -0.142 -2.774 -1.854 -2.209 [4.02]

Row and column labels: spray
Upper triangle: P values   adjust = "tukey"
Diagonal: [Estimates] (emmean) 
Lower triangle: Comparisons (estimate)   earlier vs. later
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
pwpp(m2_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-2.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
pairs(m2_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 6 estimates
```

:::
:::


## alternativa 2 - não paramétrico


::: {.cell hash='aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_83556d637a3eac1b31ab3776f8032c00'}

```{.r .cell-code}
kruskal.test(count ~ spray,
             data = inseticida)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test

data:  count by spray
Kruskal-Wallis chi-squared = 54.691, df = 5, p-value = 1.511e-10
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
m3 <- kruskal(inseticida$count,
        inseticida$spray,
        group = TRUE)

m3
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
$statistics
     Chisq Df      p.chisq  t.value      MSD
  54.69134  5 1.510845e-10 1.996564 8.462804

$parameters
            test p.ajusted           name.t ntr alpha
  Kruskal-Wallis      none inseticida$spray   6  0.05

$means
  inseticida.count     rank      std  r Min Max   Q25  Q50   Q75

D         4.916667 25.58333 2.503028 12   2  12  3.75  5.0  5.00
E         3.500000 19.33333 1.732051 12   1   6  2.75  3.0  5.00

attr(,"class")
[1] "group"
```
:::
:::


## alternativa 3 - GLMs


::: {.cell hash='aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_760d22c503f47ef2029a3f55857064d9'}

```{.r .cell-code}
m4 <- glm(count ~ spray,
          family = poisson,
          data = inseticida)

summary(m4)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

Call:
glm(formula = count ~ spray, family = poisson, data = inseticida)

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
(Intercept)  2.67415    0.07581  35.274  < 2e-16 ***
sprayB       0.05588    0.10574   0.528    0.597    
sprayC      -1.94018    0.21389  -9.071  < 2e-16 ***
sprayD      -1.08152    0.15065  -7.179 7.03e-13 ***
sprayE      -1.42139    0.17192  -8.268  < 2e-16 ***
sprayF       0.13926    0.10367   1.343    0.179    
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

(Dispersion parameter for poisson family taken to be 1)

    Null deviance: 409.041  on 71  degrees of freedom
Residual deviance:  98.329  on 66  degrees of freedom
AIC: 376.59

Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 5
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
anova(m4)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Analysis of Deviance Table

Model: poisson, link: log

Response: count

Terms added sequentially (first to last)

      Df Deviance Resid. Df Resid. Dev
NULL                     71     409.04
spray  5   310.71        66      98.33
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
Anova(m4)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Analysis of Deviance Table (Type II tests)

Response: count
      LR Chisq Df Pr(>Chisq)    
spray   310.71  5  < 2.2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(simulateResiduals(m4))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
m4_medias <- emmeans(m4, ~spray,
                     type = "response")

cld(m4_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
 spray  rate    SE  df asymp.LCL asymp.UCL .group
 C      2.08 0.417 Inf      1.41      3.08  1    
 E      3.50 0.540 Inf      2.59      4.74  12   
 D      4.92 0.640 Inf      3.81      6.35   2

 B     15.33 1.130 Inf     13.27     17.72    3  
 F     16.67 1.179 Inf     14.51     19.14    3  

Confidence level used: 0.95 
Intervals are back-transformed from the log scale 
P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 6 estimates 
Tests are performed on the log scale 
significance level used: alpha = 0.05 
NOTE: If two or more means share the same grouping symbol,
      then we cannot show them to be different.
      But we also did not show them to be the same. 
```
:::
:::


## Transformação box-cox

No RStudio, a transformação de Box-Cox é uma técnica útil para normalizar dados que não seguem uma distribuição normal, o que pode ser um pressuposto importante para diversos métodos estatísticos. Essa transformação permite adequar os dados à forma de uma curva em forma de sino, o que facilita a interpretação dos resultados e a confiabilidade das análises.


::: {.cell hash='aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_6c9d6495d31db793b0c3c83dc740de87'}

```{.r .cell-code}
b <- boxcox(lm(inseticida$count + 0.1 ~ 1))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
lambda <- b$x[which.max(b$y)]
max(b$y)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] -152.8176
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
inseticida$count3 <- (inseticida$count ^ lambda - 1) / lambda
inseticida$count3
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

:::
:::


## dados da internet


::: {.cell hash='aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_c1624a21998c081b9476d323d99fd9c6'}

```{.r .cell-code}
li <- gsheet2tbl("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1bq2N19DcZdtax2fQW9OHSGMR0X2__Z9T/edit#gid=2023059672")

li |>
  ggplot(aes(factor(dose), severity, color = factor(dose)))+
  geom_jitter(width =0.1)+
  facet_wrap(~treat)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## modelo fatorial (two-way anova)


::: {.cell hash='aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-10_cf029851f79917d971b35d444793a499'}

```{.r .cell-code}
mf <- lm(severity ~ treat*factor(dose), 
         data = li)

anova(mf)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Analysis of Variance Table

Response: severity
                   Df   Sum Sq  Mean Sq F value    Pr(>F)    
treat               1 0.113232 0.113232  30.358 4.754e-05 ***
factor(dose)        1 0.073683 0.073683  19.755 0.0004077 ***
treat:factor(dose)  1 0.072739 0.072739  19.502 0.0004326 ***
Residuals          16 0.059678 0.003730                      
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(simulateResiduals(mf))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
mf_medias <- emmeans(mf, ~ treat | dose)
cld(mf_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
dose = 0.5:
 treat        emmean     SE df lower.CL upper.CL .group
 Tebuconazole 0.0210 0.0273 16 -0.03690   0.0789  1    
 Ionic liquid 0.2921 0.0273 16  0.23420   0.3500   2   

dose = 2.0:
 treat        emmean     SE df lower.CL upper.CL .group
 Tebuconazole 0.0202 0.0273 16 -0.03768   0.0781  1    
 Ionic liquid 0.0501 0.0273 16 -0.00781   0.1080  1
```
